data.title: Name Dropping: Focus Agriculture class graduates
data.meta_description: It’s that time of year again.November marks graduation time for Focus Agriculture, a program developed by Agri-Culture that allows community leaders a firsthand experience in understanding agriculture in Santa Cruz County and the Pajaro Valley. The nine-session program covers topics such as ethnic groups in agriculture, labor, new technology, land use, politics, the environment and […]
data.text:
It’s that time of year again.

November marks graduation time for Focus Agriculture, a program developed by Agri-Culture that allows community leaders a firsthand experience in understanding agriculture in Santa Cruz County and the Pajaro Valley.

The nine-session program covers topics such as ethnic groups in agriculture, labor, new technology, land use, politics, the environment and health care.

A ceremony and reception were recently held at the Pajaro Valley Historical Association’s Bockius-Orr house on Beach Street in Watsonville to celebrate the Class XXVII of the Focus Agriculture program. The graduation ceremony included a graduation certificate plus an Assembly Certificate prepared and presented by Assemblyman Luis Alejo’s office.

Agri-Culture President Steve Bontadelli said this graduating class was an excellent on.

“ We are appreciative of the speakers and participants for giving their time during the year,” he was quoted as saying.

The members of the 2016 Focus Agriculture class are:

Jacques Bertrand, Councilmember, City of Capitola; David Brody, executive director, First 5 Santa Cruz County; Cameron Chabre, conservation land manager, Land Trust of Santa Cruz County; Doron Comerchero executive director, FoodWhat; Marie Cubillas, executive director, Big Brothers Big Sisters of Santa Cruz County; Cynthia Druley, executive director, CASA of Santa Cruz County; Marcelle Dupraw, managing senior mediator and facilitator, CSU Sacramento, Center for Collaborative Policy; Angela Gile, field representative, California State Assembly – Mark Stone; Stephen Gray, chief administrative officer, Sutter Health, Sutter Maternity and Surgery Center; Jan Kamman, community/corporate relations director, Second Harvest Food Bank of Santa Cruz County; Kathie Keely, retired – director of sales, Santa Cruz Seaside Company; Rachel Kippen, special projects coordinator, City of Watsonville; Erin Larrus, agriculture teacher, Pajaro Valley Unified School District; Barbara Mendenhall, senior trial attorney, Zenith Insurance Company; Bruce Nicholson, co-founder/principal, The Nicholson Company; Josh Schneider, president, Blue Water Construction, Inc.; Francisco Rodriguez, assistant vice president/SBA loan officer, Santa Cruz County Bank; Keith Rushing, self-employed Coldwell Banker Realtor; Mary Russell, broker/principal, Mortgage Results; Jenni Veitch-Olson, preschool founding director, United Presbyterian Church of Watsonville; and Mike Watson property manager, Shikuma Farms.

The power of community

The Agricultural History Project held its 31st annual Harvest Dinner on Oct. 29, and the sold-out event was bustling with community support.

“It’s quite humbling to be part of an organization whose community is so supportive of our cause,” John Kegebein, volunteer CEO, was quoted as saying. “We are only able to accomplish our mission through the generous support of our members, organizations in our community, volunteers and our hard-working board of directors.”

On behalf of the board of directors, the Agricultural History Project President Lindsey Roberts, along with Kegebein, introduced their organization’s endowment fund.

The funds are maintained through a partnership with the Community Foundation of Santa Cruz County, Roberts said.

“The money contributed is permanently invested and increases in value based on the investment,” Roberts was quoted as saying. “These funds help ensure the ﬁscal and physical longevity of AHP.”

All contributors of $1,000 or greater receive a lifetime membership at the Agricultural History Project. At the Harvest Dinner, the organization raised more than $27,000, resulting in 18 new Life Members.

“The campaign is off to a great start,” Kegebein was quoted as saying. “Our goal is to raise enough money to grow our endowment fund to $3 million in the coming decade.”

Guardian Angels

Holy Cross School celebrated Feast Day of the Guardian Angels with some sweet treats.

Second grader Ben Cube passed out “guardian angel” sugar cookies to his classmates, in honor of the Feast Day of the Guardian Angels, traditionally recognized on Oct. 2. His mom, Analicia Cube, bakes the angel cookies every year for the entire school, preschool through 8th grade, in celebration of the event. The children also learn a traditional Spanish guardian angel prayer.

Skimshady marks milestone

The Skimshady Show has hit triple digits.

Dana “Skimshady” Baldzikowski, AKA Skim, celebrated his 100th episode on Community TV of Santa Cruz County this month, his goal since launching the program more than eight years ago at the age of 16.

The program features local and international athletes, surfing, skateboarding and skimboarding in the waters of Santa Cruz to Hawaii to Mexico.

Skimshady films, produces and edits each show. He was named Rookie Producer of the Year at CTVSCC in 2007, and earned “Best in Show” at the 2010 Transworld Surf/ California Surf Festival Grom Film Awards for his video “Born and Raised.” He also earned the honor from the Surfrider Foundation Surf-Shorts Film Festival in 2012 to represent Santa Cruz during its’ induction as a World Surfing Reserve. He has produced four feature films, shown in local theatres.

Catch the Skimshady Show at 8 p.m. Fridays on CTVSCC, Channel 27.

Got a story to tell, an event to report, an award to announce? Tell Justine. Email her at sentinelnamedropping@gmail.com.
